BDS Syllabus 2024: Subjects, Semester-wise Syllabus PDF, Top Colleges, Books

Updated on Mar 14, 2024 02:53 IST

Parul ThapaSenior Executive Content

The BDS or Bachelor of Dental Surgery is a four-year bachelor's degree programme to become a dentist. It is an undergraduate-level course where students learn to diagnose, prevent, and treat illnesses, disorders, and oral cavity ailments. Students who have studied science stream with biology in classes 11 and 12 can opt for a BDS course. The programme includes four years of classroom study and several practicals, followed by a one-year compulsory internship in hospitals and clinics.

Table of Contents
  1. Syllabus: Important Facts for BDS
  2. List of Subjects in BDS

    • 2.2 Typical Elective Subjects for BDS

Syllabus: Important Facts for BDS

Duration of the course

BDS is a five-year undergraduate course with a four-year classroom study followed by one year of internship. Upon completing the five-year course, students are awarded the BDS degree, which authorises them to practice as dentists.

Syllabus of the course

The syllabus of the BDS course includes core and elective subjects and practical subjects. These subjects are General Pathology, Microbiology, General and Dental Pharmacology, Dental Therapeutics, Preclinical Conservative Dentistry, Oral Pathology, and Oral Microbiology.

Scope

The BDS course allows the degree holders to practice as a dentist. Dentists can pursue their practice through a private clinic or seek employment in private or government hospitals.

Examination Pattern

The examination pattern for BDS includes semester papers, practical examinations, and internships. The scheme of the examination is such that it includes theory papers, internal assessments, viva voce, and practical examinations.

After BDS

Upon completing the programme, students receive their BDS degree. To strengthen their understanding and achieve expertise in a specific field of dentistry, they can opt for a master's course. The MDS or Master’s of Dental Surgery is a three-year course to pursue after BDS.

List of Subjects in BDS

Typical Core Subjects for BDS

Subject title

Subject Details

Human Anatomy, Embryology, Histology, and Medical Genetics

The subject deals with the introduction of anatomical terms and a brief outline of various systems of the body, Regional anatomy of head & neck with osteology of bones of head & neck, with emphasis on topics of dental importance; The regional anatomy of the sites of intramuscular & intravascular injections, & lumbar

punctures are also discussed.

Human Physiology

Students learn about the basic concept of Homeostasis, Feedback mechanisms; Blood and its components; Muscle and nerve; Digestive system; Excretory system; Endocrinology; Reproduction; Body temperature; Respiratory system; Central Nervous System

Biochemistry

Through this subject, students learn about the Biochemical basis of the life processes relevant to the human system and dental/medical practice. They understand the Chemistry of Bioorganic molecules; Macronutrients and Digestion; Micronutrients; Energy metabolism; Enzyme and metabolic regulation

General And Dental Pharmacology And Therapeutics

As future dentists, students understand the general principles of pharmacology; sources and nature of drugs dosage forms; prescription writing; pharmacokinetics; CNS drugs; General anaesthetics; Drugs acting on blood; Endocrines and Chemotherapy

Orthodontics & Dental Orthopaedics

The subject includes the diagnosis, analysis, and processes for treating orthodontic issues. It also includes Morphologic Development of Craniofacial Structures; Functional Development Of Dental Arches And Occlusion; Malocclusion and its classification, Normal And Abnormal Function Of Stomatognathic System

Paediatric & Preventive Dentistry

The subject includes the study of growth and development in Pedodontics, Prenatal and Postnatal factors in growth & development, Study of variations and abnormalities, Development of teeth and associated structures, Chronology of eruption of teeth, Indications and contraindications of extractions of primary and permanent teeth in children, Knowledge of Local and General Anaesthesia

Public Health Dentistry

The subject introduces Health & Disease: Concepts, Philosophy, Definition and Characteristics; Public Health- Definition & Concepts, History of public health; Environmental Health; Public Health Administration; Nutrition in oral diseases; Health-care delivery system

Periodontology

It is a core dental subject that teaches the definition of Periodontology, Periodontics, Periodontia, Brief historical background, Scope of Periodontics; Age changes in

periodontal structures and their significance in Geriatric dentistry; Classification of periodontal diseases, Gingival diseases, Epidemiology of periodontal diseases

Prosthodontics And Crown & Bridge

Students understand various aspects of applied Anatomy and Physiology, Diagnosis and treatment planning for patients, Components of a removable partial denture, Survey and design, Mouth preparation and master cast; Principles of tooth preparations, Preparations for full and partial veneer crowns

Typical Elective Subjects for BDS

Subject Title

Subject Details

Aesthetic Dentistry

This elective subject deals with the aspects of the smile, esthetic forms of dentistry, procedures to enhance the overall look of smile and face, and chemical procedures such as beaching to enhance visual characteristics.

Forensic odontology

Introduction to forensic dentistry, Overview of forensic medicine and toxicology, Cause of death and postmortem changes, Toxicological manifestations in teeth and oral tissues; Basis for dental identification, Postmortem procedures, Dental record compilation and interpretation

Ethics

Introduction to ethics, Ethics of the individual – The patient as a person, Right to be respected; Profession Ethics –

Code of conduct Contract and confidentiality, Charging of fees, fee-splitting; Prescription of drugs, Over-investigating the patient, Malpractice and negligence; Research Ethics – Animal and experimental research/humanness; Human experimentation

Human volunteer research-informed consent Drug trials

Behavioural Sciences

The subject helps in developing the understanding of behavioural factors of dentistry, explaining stress, learning simple counselling techniques, and improving patients’ compliance behaviour; Diagnosing and managing minor psychological problems while treating dental patients.

Oral Implantology

The subject of oral implantology introduces the concepts of implantations in the mouth, various aspects of implantology, and finding and treating related issues.

Entrance Exam for BDS

For admission to BDS programmes, aspirants must take the NEET-UG examination. The NEET-UG or National entrance-cum-eligibility test is a national-level exam conducted for admission to medical, dental, and ayurvedic programmes in India. It is conducted by the national testing agency (NTA). The test is to be taken using an OMR sheet in pen and paper mode.

NEET-UG is a three-hour-long examination with 180 questions. The test includes four sections, each for one subject from Physics, Chemistry, Botany, and Zoology. Each section has two subsections; section A has 35 questions, and section B has 15 questions. Each correct answer fetches four marks, while there is a negative marking of one mark for each wrong answer. Students can select their preferred choice of language to take the test. There are a total of 13 languages available to opt for the test.

The difficulty level of the exam is moderate to difficult, with lakhs of aspirants for some thousands of seats. The cutoff for MBBS courses is the highest, followed by the cutoff for BDS courses. Aspirants must have completed a minimum of seventeen years and should not be more than twenty five years of age when writing the test. There is also an eligibility criterion for students to have studied English, Physics, Chemistry and Biology in 12th standard for appearing in the NEET-UG test.

Syllabus for Distance Programme in BDS

The BDS or Bachelor of Dental Surgery programme is only available as a full-time regular course. There is no option of distance or online course for the BDS programme.

BDS Syllabus: Frequently Asked Questions (FAQs)

Q. What is the BDS course?

A. The BDS or Bachelor of Dental Surgery is the undergraduate course in dentistry in India. It is a five-year long course with four years of study and one year of internship.

Q. What subjects are included in the BDS course?

A. Some of the subjects included in the BDS course are General human Physiology, Biochemistry, General Pathology, Paediatric & Preventive Dentistry, and Periodontology.

Q. Which practicals are done during the BDS course?

A. The practical subjects in the curriculum of the BDS programme include Dental Anatomy, Embryology, and Oral Histology, Microbiology, Conservative Dentistry & Endodontics, Prosthodontics & Crown & Bridge.

Q. Which entrance exam is given for admission to the BDS programme?

A. The most famous and widely taken medical entrance examination in India is NEET or the National Entrance cum Eligibility Test. NEET-UG is conducted to get admission to private and government medical colleges for MBBS, BDS, and BAMS programmes.

Q. What is the scope of a BDS programme?

A. After completing the BDS programme, the student receives the BDS degree, which entitles them to practice as a dentist in the country. Students can further pursue masters or begin their practice with a bachelor’s degree.

Q. Which course can I pursue after the BDS programme?

A. After the BDS programme, dentists can opt for the MDS or Master of Dental Surgery programme. Students can also opt for a specific specialisation for their MDS course, or study a diploma course instead of the MDS programme.

Q. What are the top colleges to pursue BDS?

A. The top colleges in India to pursue BDS are AIIMS, Manipal College of Dental Studies, King George’s Medical University Lucknow, Government Dental College Bengaluru, and Dr. D. Y. Patil Vidyapeeth.

Q. Is it possible to pursue BDS without giving the NEET examination?

A. It is mandatory for all BDS aspirants to take the NEET-UG examination to get admission to the programme. Admission to private, government and all categories of medical colleges is done through NEET-UG counselling.

Q. What is the difference between MBBS and BDS?

A. MBBS is the UG course for becoming a doctor, while BDS is the UG course to become a dentist in India. MBBS stands for Bachelor of Medicine and Bachelor of Surgery, while BDS stands for Bachelor of Dental Surgery.

Q. What is the difference between BDS and BAMS?

A. BDS or the Bachelor of Dental Surgery is the undergraduate course to become a dentist, while BAMS or the Bachelor of Ayurveda, Medicine, and Surgery is the UG course to become an ayurvedic doctor.

Q. What are the specialisations in dentistry?

A. The specialisations in Dentistry include Oral & Maxillofacial Surgery, Oral Medicine and Radiology, Pedodontics & Preventive Dentistry, Prosthodontics and Crown & Bridge, Periodontology, Orthodontics & Dentofacial Orthopaedics, and Conservative Dentistry.

Q. Are dentists allowed to use ‘Dr.’ in front of their name?

A. Yes. As BDS includes the word surgery, dentists are allowed to use the prefix Dr. before their names.

Q. What is the age limit for NEET?

A. The lower age limit for NEET-UG is seventeen years. The upper age limit for UR or unreserved aspirants is 25 years, while for reserved category students, the upper age limit is 30 years.

Q. What was the cutoff for NEET 2021?

A. In 2021, the NEET-UG cutoff was 720-138 for unreserved candidates, 137-122 for General-PH candidates, 137-108 for SC, ST, and OBC candidates.
